poem:
**Innocence Stained**

In the cold corridors of justice,  
where whispered truths are silenced,  
men wear the shadows of guilt,  
beyond their broken dreams.  
Coins of compensation, tarnished,  
clink bitterly in hollow bowls.  
O, the burden of proving purity,  
against the darkened tide,  
the soul's outcry  
drowns in bureaucracy's indifferent sea.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Raw deal for those who are wrongfully convicted | Letter Your article on Andrew Malkinson’s initial compensation payout for wrongful conviction (12 February) reveals the horror of the situation for applicants to the government’s mean-spirited and legally illiterate compensation scheme. The change to the law in 2014, which means those wrongfully convicted must overturn their conviction and prove they are innocent “beyond all reasonable doubt”, has seen payouts collapse. Between 1999 and 2007, 307 applicants". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
